titleStmt.title: The Parliaments instructions agreed on by the Lords and Commons for to be observed by their severall committees, now residing in the severall counties, and those to be imployed. Likewise, the message and order of both Houses of Parliament to the aldermen of the city of London, August the 12. 1642. Wherein is declared their desires to the said aldermen, for to appear on monday next at the time and place herein prefixed. Ordered that this be forthwith printed and published John. Brown. Cler. Parl.

notesStmt.note: Wing says this is a spurious document with a false imprint.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE PARLIAMENTS INSTRUCTIONS Agreed on by the Lords and Commons for to be ob≈øerved by their ≈øeverall Committees, now Re≈øiding in the ≈øeverall Counties, and tho≈øe to be imployed.
LIKEWISE, The Me≈ø≈øage and Order of both Hou≈øes of Parliament to the Alderman of the City of London, Augu≈øt the 12. 1642.
Wherein is Declared their De≈øires to the ≈øaid Aldermen, for to appear on monday next at the time and place herein prefixed.
Ordered that this be forthwith printed and publi≈øhed
LONDON: Printed for J. Han≈øott. Augu≈øt 16. 16 ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢

div.head: Die Veneris Augu≈øti 1642. In≈øtructions agreed on by the Lords and Commons in Parliament, for to be ob≈øerved by their ≈øeverall Committees.
I.
div.p: YOu ≈øhall ob≈øerve and execute the Ordinance of both Hou≈øes of Parliament the eighth of this month, for the ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion of the Rebellion and Commotion, rai≈øed by the Marque≈ø≈øe of Hartford in the County of Somer≈øet, and other We≈øtern Counties; and by the Earle of Northampton and others in the County of Leice≈øter Northampton, Warwick, and other adjoyning parts.

div.head: II.
div.p:
You ≈øhall conduct and leade all ≈øuch Forces of Hor≈øe and Foot as ≈øhall be appointed by the Lord Generall (the Earle of E≈ø≈øex) for this ≈øervice, and ≈øhall fight with, kill, and ≈ølay all ≈øuch as ≈øhall by force oppo≈øe you in the execution of that Ordinance, and all their A≈øsi≈øtants, Ayders, and Abettors, and you ≈øhall levie ≈øuch other Forces of hor≈øe and foot, as his Excellence ≈øhall by his Commi≈ø≈øion give you power to leavie, under ≈øuch Colonels,
Commanders, and other Officers, as ≈øhall bee by him appointed or directed? And you ≈øhall pur≈øue the ≈øaid Rebels and Traytors, in the ≈øaid Counties, or in any other Counties, or parts of the Kingdome into which they ≈øhall retyre them≈øelves.

All which Forces ≈øo to be rai≈øed ≈øhall have the ≈øame pay as the re≈øt of the Army is to have. And you ≈øhall defend and protect his Maje≈øties Subjects from violence and oppre≈ø≈øion by the illegall Commi≈ø≈øion of Array, or otherwi≈øe; And you ≈øhall hinder and forbid the execution of that illegall Commi≈ø≈øion, and in all places to the uttermo≈øt of your power, indeavour to pre≈øerve and re≈øtore the peace of the Kingdome.

div.head: III.
div.p: You are hereby authorized and required to di≈øarme all popi≈øh Recu≈øants, and all ≈øuch other dangerous and ill-affected per≈øons, as well Clergy men as others, as have te≈øtified or ≈øhall te≈øtifie their ill-di≈øpo≈øition to the peace of the Kingdom.

div.head: IV.
div.p:
You ≈øhall indeavour to cleere the proceedings of Parliament from all imputations and A≈øper≈øions, and ≈øhall from time to time certifie us of all things nece≈ø≈øary for the publique ≈øervice, and that wee may have a ≈øpeedy account of it, and directions to you, a≈øwell as your adverti≈øements to us may have a cleer and ready pa≈ø≈øage, you ≈øhall lay a ≈øtrict charg upon all po≈øt-ma≈øters, that they doe not ≈øuffer any Letters, or other Di≈øpatches, to or from the Parliament, to be intercepted or ≈øtayed: or if any ≈øhall
pre≈øume to make ≈øuch ≈øtay of tho≈øe Di≈øpatches, you ≈øhall direct the Po≈øtma≈øters to repaire to the Ju≈øtices of the Peace, Con≈øtables, and all other Officers, for their Aid and A≈ø≈øi≈øtance, who are hereby required to take ≈øpeciall care that there may not be no ≈øuch interruption.

div.head: V.
div.p: If you ≈øhall find any di≈øaffected per≈øons, rai≈øing any parties again≈øt the Parliament, ≈øpreading ≈øcandals or a≈øper≈øions on their proceedings, like to di≈øturbe the peace of the Kingdom; you ≈øhall cau≈øe all ≈øuch per≈øons (upon good proofes of their Mi≈ødemeanours) to be Arre≈øted and ≈øent up to an≈øwer ≈øuch their Offences, as to Law and Ju≈øtice ≈øhall appertain.

div.head: VI.
div.p: You ≈øhall take from the ≈øaid Rebels and Traytors all ≈øuch Arms, Ordinance, and Ammunition, as they have taken from his Maje≈øties Subjects, and re≈øtore the ≈øame to the Owner.

div.head: VII.
div.p: Whereas his Maje≈øty ≈øeduced by wicked Councels hath rai≈øed Warre again≈øt his Parliament, and other his good ≈øubjects, and hath drawn together great troops of Papi≈øts and ill affected per≈øons, and ≈øent out Commi≈ø≈øion for the levying of others, to the great hazzard of Religion, and the publique peace of the Kingdome.

You are therfore required to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe all per≈øons what≈øoever, who ≈øhall leavie any Souldiers, or draw together any of the Trayned Bands, by colour or pretence of any Commi≈ø≈øion from his Maje≈øty, under the great Seal or otherwi≈øe; And you ≈øhall ceize upon all Hor≈øes, Arms, Ammunition, money, Plate, or other Provi≈øion what≈øoever, rai≈øed or provided under pretence of his Maje≈øties ≈øervice, for the fomenting or maintaining any ≈øuch unnaturall and unlawfull warre again≈øt his people.

div.head: VIII.
div.p: You ≈øhall ob≈øerve and execute all ≈øuch further Directions and In≈øtructions as you ≈øhall from time to time receive from both Hou≈øes of Parliament; As likewi≈øe, ≈øuch In≈øtructions and Directions as you ≈øhal from time to time receive from the Committees of the Lords and Commons appointed to take Care of the ≈øafety of the Kingdom, and what≈øoever you ≈øhall do therein, or any other per≈øon in Aid or A≈ø≈øi≈øtance of you, it ≈øhall be accepted as a good and nece≈ø≈øary ≈øervice to the Kingdom, and for their and your ≈øo doing, they and you ≈øhall bee defended and protected by the Authority of Parliament. And this Re≈øolution of the Lords and Commons, to protect tho≈øe that ≈øhall obey and further their Commands, you ≈øhal publi≈øh and declare upon all occa≈øions, for the better encouragement of the Subjects of this Kingdom in that behalfe.

div.head: Die Veneris 12. Augu≈øti. 1642.
div.p: IT is this Day Ordered by the Lords and Commons a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament, That every Alderman in every Ward within the City of London, or in his ab≈øence his Deputy, ≈øhall ≈øummon every Sub≈øidy man dwelling in his ≈øaid Ward to appear on Monday next, at their u≈øuall place of meeting by 8. of the clock in the morning, where ≈øome members of the Hou≈øe of Commons will be pre≈øent to acquaint them with the pre≈øent ≈øtate and condition of the Kingdom, and City of London, and to con≈øider further what is fit for the ≈øafety of both.

And to that end you are to require all Inhabitants ≈øetting all excu≈øes a≈øide, not to fail of giving their per≈øonall pre≈øence at the time and place appointed by you. And every Alderman or Deputy is likewi≈øe hereby further required, upon the
day and time above-≈øpecified, to make return of the ≈øub≈øcriptions of all ≈øtrangers in their particular Wards.

closer.signed: Ordered by the Lords and Commons a≈øsembled in Parliament, that this be forthwith printed and publi≈øhed. Iohn Brown Cler. Parl.
